abstract.para: The &firewalld; Linux system role in Ansible is a pre-packaged and reusable set of tasks and defaults designed to configure and manage the &firewalld; service on &productname; 16.0 systems.

topic.para: You can use this role to:

listitem.para: Manage zones such as public, home or internal.
Add or remove services such as ssh to specific zones.
Open or close ports, for example, 8080 or TCP for particular zones.

example.title: Reset firewall and enable SSH service
example.screen:
--- - name: Erase existing config and enable ssh service hosts: examplehost
vars: firewall: - previous: replaced - service: ssh state: enabled roles: - linux-system-roles.firewall

listitem.para: name: Describes task of erasing all existing configurations and enabling SSH service.
hosts: Defines the managed nodes on which tasks and roles from the playbook will be executed.
previous: replaced: Resets the &firewalld; configuration by removing all existing user-defined settings.
service: ssh: Secure Shell (SSH) as the specific network traffic type to be managed.
state: enabled: Permanently opens the firewall for incoming SSH traffic.
roles: Loads and run the tasks, variables, and handlers defined within the specified roles. In this example, the linux-system-roles.firewall is used.

example.title: Disable tftpservice
example.screen:
--- - name: disable tftp service hosts: examplehost
vars: firewall: - service: tftp state: disabled roles: - linux-system-roles.firewall

listitem.para: name: Describes task of erasing all existing configurations and enabling SSH service.
hosts: Defines the managed nodes on which tasks and roles from the playbook will be executed.
service: tftp: Defines the Trivial File Transfer Protocol (TFTP) as the specific network service to be managed.
state: disabled: Permanently block all incoming network traffic related to tftp.
roles: Loads and run the tasks, variables, and handlers defined within the specified roles. In this example, the linux-system-roles.firewall is used.
